Description: The adoption of omic technologies in large-scale cancer studies and the increasing availability of primary data from public resources present opportunities and challenges for developing predictive models. This session will highlight approaches such as machine learning methods for prediction with high-dimensional data generated by these technologies. The promise and practical limitations of these approaches will be discussed. Should we be surprised when a model trained in a single study fails to generalize to an external study? How can we integrate pre-analytical and technical sources of variation between studies as part of model training and validation? Translation of these predictors to clinically useful tests requires a roadmap that encompasses consideration of the ultimate clinical use, careful experimental design, and rigorous application of statistical procedures to evaluate performance.
SearchResultBody: ED022. Developing Replicable Genomic Classifiers of Cancer
Title: Developing Replicable Genomic Classifiers of Cancer
